Cartesian form

On occasions it is useful to convert the vector form of the equation of a straight line into Cartesian form.

Suppose we write \(\underline{ a}=\begin{bmatrix}a_1 \\ a_2 \\ a_3 \end{bmatrix},\; \underline{ b}=\begin{bmatrix}b_1 \\ b_2 \\ b_3 \end{bmatrix},\; \underline{ r} = \begin{bmatrix}x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix}\) then \(\underline{ r} = \underline{ a} + t(\underline{ b}-\underline{ a})\) implies \(\; \begin{bmatrix}x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}a_1 \\ a_2 \\ a_3 \end{bmatrix} +t\begin{bmatrix} b_1-a_1 \\ b_2-a_2 \\ b_3-a_3\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}a_1 + t(b_1-a_1) \\ a_2 + t(b_2-a_2) \\ a_3 + t(b_3-a_3) \end{bmatrix}\)

Equating the individual components we find

\(x = a_1 + t(b_1-a_1), \;\hbox{ or equivalently } t=\dfrac{x-a_1}{b_1-a_1}\)

\(y = a_2 + t(b_2-a_2), \;\hbox{ or equivalently } t=\dfrac{y-a_2}{b_2-a_2}\)

\(z = a_3 + t(b_3-a_3), \;\hbox{ or equivalently } t=\dfrac{z-a_3}{b_3-a_3}\)

Each expression on the right is equal to \(t\) and so we can write \(\dfrac{x-a_1}{b_1-a_1} = \dfrac{y-a_2}{b_2-a_2}=\dfrac{z-a_3}{b_3-a_3}.\) This gives the Cartesian form of the equations of the straight line which passes through the points with coordinates \((a_1,a_2,a_3)\) and \((b_1,b_2,b_3)\).

Key Point

The Cartesian form of the equation of the straight line which passes through the points with coordinates \((a_1,a_2,a_3)\) and \((b_1,b_2,b_3)\) is \[\frac{x-a_1}{b_1-a_1} = \frac{y-a_2}{b_2-a_2}=\frac{z-a_3}{b_3-a_3}.\]
